Robin van Persie - The Modern-Day Footballer

05/07/2012

Jack Bradshaw gives his take on the Robin van Persie transfer saga, after the striker announced that he will not be signing a new contract at Arsenal (Thumbnail credit Image: Ronnie Macdonald via flickr Creative Commons)

Image by

By undefined undefined

Like every other Gooner, up until yesterday evening I loved Robin van Persie. He was Arsenal's captain, talisman and undoubtedly one of the best strikers in the world. As money and business continues to enslave modern-day football and its mercenaries, it seemed van Persie was different to the others who have left Arsenal in recent years; notably Messrs Nasri and Adebayor. Van Persie had led from the front in spectacular fashion for the last 18 months, had transformed the morale of the dressing-room no-end, and had always acted with the utmost respect to the club and the fans. But now here we are. Another summer, another captain on his way out of the club, leaving behind fans bickering about whose fault it is and what could have been done differently. I would and will never criticise a player taking a forward step in his career; with clear, understandable motives behind the move - Cesc Fabregas is still my favourite footballer despite his move to Barcelona last summer. I have said all along that van Persie deserves to win trophies and deserves to play for one of the best sides in the world, and thus would have accepted him moving on to bigger and better things, as much as I hoped he would stay. What I cannot accept however, is when players treat Arsenal and Arsene Wenger with utter contempt, as van Persie did yesterday, and Samir Nasri did last summer. Van Persie released a statement yesterday on his own personal website, stating that he would not be renewing his contract at the Emirates, without the club and Wenger knowing. Regardless of whether he is the best player and captain or not, he is still one of many players employed by the club, and the fact that he went behind their back is completely unacceptable. Moreover, despite the pretence of directing his statement at the fans, whom he claims to still love, he openly criticised the way the club is run. The club which gave him his big break, the club which turned him into a centre-forward, the club which stuck by him for seven injury plagued seasons, the club which sold Emmanuel Adebayor and entrusted him as first choice. Arsenal is the club that made van Persie the player he is today and he has completely disrespected them, and with that lost his chance to be considered in the same legendary bracket as Thierry Henry and Dennis Bergkamp. By releasing this statement with a year still to run on his contract, he forces Arsenal's and any potential suitors' hands, despite protesting not to. Wenger is known not to keep want-away players at his club as it can have a detrimental effect, so now he is forced to sell at what will inevitably be a knock-down price to one of Europe's leading clubs, most likely Manchester City. Van Persie has stated a lack of ambition and difference in ideas as the reasons behind his departure. Wenger has already worked quickly this summer to secure the signings of Lukas Podolski and Olivier Giroud, from Cologne and Montpellier respectively. Two top-quality international strikers, with age on their side, who between them scored 39 league goals last season (Podolski in a relegated team, Giroud firing his side to an unprecedented title and winning the golden boot). What clearer sign of intent could van Persie have possibly wanted before the start of July? I would be fascinated to know in what other ways he expects the board to match his burning ambition for the club other than spend money that Arsenal simply do not have on enormous wages. If he wants success, he should join Barcelona, long-term admirers Juventus, or even PSG. However, he will most likely join Manchester City who will pay him the most money. I could handle him going abroad for success and have always believed he would never play for another side in England, but his actions reek of greed. BBC Radio 5Live reporter Ian McGarry reported recently that a deal had already been agreed between the clubs for the striker's sale. And despite McGarry's somewhat questionable reputation when it comes to transfer gossip, it would make sense to suggest that van Persie had made up his mind months ago. If van Persie is to join Manchester City this summer then he is no better than Adebayor or Nasri. It is worth noting that Arsenal are due to play City in a pre-season "friendly" on July 27th. With the exception of Cesc, who left to return home to a club he loves, Arsenal's big money departures in the past few years have all been to City. Wenger gets results with players in a team who play in great style and after one good season, or in Nasri's case a good six months, they are sold to City because the Gunners cannot compete with them financially. So much is made of Arsenal's lack of success over the last seven seasons, but if Wenger didn't keep losing his best players, then he could build a squad capable of winning trophies, just like he did before the current deluge of foreign investors came to the Premier League. However, around Europe there are still examples of loyalty to be found. Gareth Bale, Edinson Cavani and Antonio Di Natale all committed their future to their clubs - Tottenhan, Napoli, Udinese - despite not qualifying for the UEFA Champions League for the 2012/13 season. Van Persie had this. He was also the captain and talisman of one of the biggest clubs in Euorpe, with players around him like Theo Walcott and Alex Song who he has developed an incredible understanding with. He was loved and with new signings coming in, he had the chance of leading his side to success in the coming years, just like he claimed he always wanted to. Instead he chooses to jump ship for more money and puts the club he claims to love in a terrible situation once again and move them further away from his proclaimed desire, which is for them to be successful. But so is the way of the modern-day footballer.
